raw_text:
BMW to recall faulty diesel cars
 
 BMW is to recall all cars equipped with a faulty diesel fuel-injection pump supplied by parts maker Robert Bosch.
 
 The faulty part does not represent a safety risk and the recall only affects pumps made in December and January. BMW said that it was too early to say how many cars were affected or how much the recall would cost. The German company is to extend a planned production break at one of its plants due to the faulty Bosch part. The Dingolfing site will now be closed all next week instead of for just two days. The additional three-day stoppage will mean a production loss of up to 3,600 vehicles, BMW said, adding that it was confident it could make up the numbers later.
 
 Bosch has stopped production of the part but expects to restart by 2 February. The faulty component does not represent a safety risk but causes the motor to stall after a significant amount of mileage. When asked if BMW would be seeking compensation from Bosch, the carmaker's chief executive Helmut Panke said: "we will first solve the problem before talking about who will pay". Audi and Mercedes Benz were also supplied with the defective diesel fuel-injection pumps but neither of them have to recall any vehicles. A spokesman for DaimlerChrysler, parent company of Mercedes Benz, said it will however have to halt some production. It is to close the Mercedes factory in Sindelfingen on Monday and Tuesday. Audi said it had been hit by production bottlenecks, due to a shortage of unaffected Bosch parts.
llama3.2:1b: BMW to recall all diesel cars with faulty fuel-injection pumps supplied by Robert Bosch.
The faulty part affects December and January models.
BMW will extend production break at its Dingolfing plant for three days due to the recall.
The stoppage is expected to result in a loss of up to 3,600 vehicles.
llama3.2:3b: BMW to recall all cars with faulty diesel fuel-injection pump supplied by Robert Bosch, caused motor to stall after significant mileage, with no safety risk; plant closure expected until 2 February; affected also Audi and Mercedes Benz, which halt production but do not recall vehicles.
gemma2:2b: BMW is recalling all cars equipped with faulty diesel fuel-injection pumps made by Robert Bosch between December and January.
The recall will affect production at one of its plants, leading to a 3,600 vehicle loss in the short term.
While not posing a safety risk, the faulty part causes stalling after significant mileage.
Bosch is halting production of the part but expects to resume operations on February 2nd.
Other automakers such as Audi and Mercedes-Benz are facing production disruptions due to a shortage of unaffected Bosch parts.

The company extended its planned downtime at one of its factories due to the part's failure.
While it is unclear how many cars were affected, the recall costs are estimated to be in the range of up to 3,600 vehicles.
The faulty pump does not pose a safety risk but causes diesel engines to stall after prolonged use.

The company extended a planned production break at one plant and will now close it for an additional three days due to the recall affecting 3,600 vehicles.
Bosch has stopped production of the defective part but expects to restart by February 2nd.
Audi and Mercedes-Benz also use this faulty component but do not need recalls, with DaimlerChrysler planning a temporary halt in Sindelfingen.

The recall doesn't pose safety risks but causes the motor to stall after significant mileage.

Bosch has halted production but expects to resume by February.
Audi and Mercedes-Benz were also provided with the defective pumps but no recalls are necessary.
BMW CEO Helmut Panke stated they will first resolve the problem before discussing compensation from Bosch.
DaimlerChrysler (parent of Mercedes-Benz) plans a one-day shutdown at Sindelfingen factory and production bottlenecks due to part shortages.

The recall only affects pumps made in December and January, and the carmaker has not yet disclosed how many vehicles are affected or how much it will cost.

The recall affects pumps made in December and January and does not represent a safety risk.
BMW is unsure of the number of affected vehicles or the cost of the recall.

Neither Audi nor Mercedes Benz have to recall any vehicles, with DaimlerChrysler closing one of its Sindelfingen factories and experiencing production bottlenecks due to a shortage of unaffected Bosch parts.

The recall affects around 3 million vehicles but BMW has no details on the exact number affected or the cost of the recall.
BMW will extend its production break at one of its plants, resulting in up to three production vehicles lost.

granite3.1-dense:2b: BMW announces a recall of approximately 3,600 vehicles due to faulty diesel fuel-injection pumps supplied by Robert Bosch, manufactured in December and January.
The defect causes the engine to stall after extensive use.
BMW will extend its production break at the Dingolfing plant for an additional week, resulting in a 3,600 vehicle production loss.
Bosch has ceased production of the problematic part, aiming to resume by February 2.
Audi and Mercedes Benz also received the defective pumps but won't recall vehicles, as they'll face production halts due to unaffected Bosch parts shortages.
DaimlerChrysler's Mercedes Sindelfingen factory will close for two days, while Audi experiences production bottlenecks from part scarcity.
BMW CEO, Helmut Panke, stated that compensation discussions with Bosch will follow solving the problem.
chatgpt-4o-latest: BMW is recalling all cars with faulty diesel fuel-injection pumps supplied by Bosch, though the defect does not pose a safety risk.
The recall affects pumps made in December and January, but the number of affected cars and costs remain unclear.
BMW is extending a production break at its Dingolfing plant, leading to a temporary loss of up to 3,600 vehicles, though it expects to recover production later.
Bosch has halted production of the faulty part but plans to resume by February 2.
The defect causes engine stalling after significant mileage.
BMW has not yet discussed compensation with Bosch.

Audi and Mercedes Benz also received the defective pumps but are not recalling vehicles, though Mercedes will halt production at its Sindelfingen plant for two days, and Audi faces production delays due to a shortage of unaffected Bosch parts.
